p.s: The following analysis aims to identify the language Ankita Mitra uses in her blogpost to transmit her message.
Firstly, the author explains what she means when she writes Environmental pollution.
Environmental pollution refers to the introduction of harmful pollutants into the environment(l. 1).
By doing so, the reader is informed about what exactly is meant and can follow the blogpost better.
Following that, she describes the planet earth and paints a perfect image into the reader's head: human life and other forms of existence have flourished on earth (ll. 7-8, ll. 4-8).
This results in the reader appreciating the earth and perhaps willing to protect it, if anything were to happen to it.

By then turning everything to the negative side: surge in pollution (l. 10), man [...] began losing control (l. 12), victim of his own creations (l. 12) the author not only frightens the reader, but also makes him/her aware of the appalling situation the earth they learned to love is facing.

This is then strengthened by a more detailed description of the negative effects of pollution: devastating effects on sea life, on crops and human health (l. 13), affects all plants, animal and human life in a destructing way (l. 14), at the cost of our health (l. 15), threatened with extinction (l. 16).
By introducing this wide span of effects, the author makes the reader feel threatened and feel the urge to do something against the problem discussed.

The reference to the question whether all is well with our industrial growth and progress in the field of science and technology (l. 19) stimulates the reader to think about the question him-/herself and to doubt the positive effects of industrial growth and scientifscientific or technologictechnological advance.

As the author then reminds the reader of everyday causes of pollution, for instance traffic (l. 23), synthetic detergents (l. 23), nitrogen fertilizers (l. 23) or insecticides (l. 23), the reader realises the possibilities tha the/she has to limit her/his contribution to pollution, but also how he/she is affecting the environment.
By warning the reader of the [contaminated] water we drink and [...] vegetables the reader becomes aware of how pollution is affecting everyone.
Furthermore, the inclusive language makes the reader feel addressed and included in the happening.
The example of the industrial environment tragedy [...] at Bhopal on December 3, 1984 makes it clear how severe the effects of pollution, in this case a leakage (l. 30), can be.

Finally, the author specifically stats the urgence of action: If we fail to restore the ecological balance right now, it will be too late tomorrow (l. 36), basically instructing the reader what is to be done.
Altogether, the author uses negative and inclusive language to make it clear how grave the current situation is and that the reader him- or herself can help to fix the problem.
